Identification of real objects under conditions similar to those in haptic displays: providing spatially distributed information at the contact areas is more important than increasing the number of areas
Download PDF
Download PDF
  • Original Article
  • Published: 09 March 2006

Identification of real objects under conditions similar to those in haptic displays: providing spatially distributed information at the contact areas is more important than increasing the number of areas

  • Gunnar Jansson1 &
  • Linda Monaci1,2 

Virtual Reality volume 9, pages243–249(2006)Cite this article

  • 411 Accesses

  • 32 Citations

  • Metrics details

Abstract

Present day haptic displays have one or a few contact areas, the information being similar over the whole area. The aim of this investigation was to study the relative importance of increasing the number of contact areas and providing spatially distributed information at each contact area. Technical development was “simulated” in experiments with real objects where the information was constrained in ways similar to those in haptic displays. The results suggest clearly that the largest improvement can be expected if spatially distributed information is made available within each contact area. If that is made, an improvement of performance can be expected also with an increased number of contact areas. Increasing only the number of contact areas will not give the same result.

Introduction

Haptics in Real and Virtual Worlds Compared

When used naturally, haptics alone is extraordinarily efficient in the identification of object (Klatzky et al. 1985). However, in virtual worlds where objects are explored via a haptic display this capacity is not at all fully utilized (e.g., Jansson 2000). The lower performance with the haptic displays developed so far depends probably on the fact that they do not mirror the conditions of natural haptics sufficiently well. Typically, the simultaneous information provided by haptic displays is based on what is available for one point in the virtual world. The proximal stimulus at the skin of a hand has some extension, varying with kind of display, but the information is the same over the whole surface involved. In contrast, natural haptics provides several contact areas; including up to ten fingers, as well as other parts of the hand, and each contact area consists of an extended surface with spatially distributed information.

An overview of the effects on object identification of constraints on the normal haptic exploration was made by Lederman and Klatzky (2004). They discussed two kinds of constraints, sheaths and probes, and interpreted the impaired performance as dependent on losses of cutaneous and/or kinesthetic information. They also applied the results to haptic displays, as the constraints of information in these devices are similar to those they studied experimentally. In the present paper the effects of the two main properties causing constraints in the information, as discussed in Lederman and Klatzky (2004), are investigated: number of exploring fingers and spatially distributed cutaneous information. These properties were selected, as they are related to two options for improving haptic displays: increasing the number of contact areas and increasing the cutaneous information made available at each contact area.

One- and two-finger exploration of 2D patterns

In the context of Braille reading the use of more than one finger was studied by Foulke (1971). He found some evidence that an increase of the “perceptual window” by providing readers with Braille cells simultaneously available for the different fingers improved reading. However, in another study (Lappin and Foulke 1973) there were no better results from reading Braille with two fingers. This may explain why most Braille readers use only one finger for reading (Hollins 2000, p. 344).

Concerning perception of outline 2D shapes of familiar objects, little improvement has been found by using two fingers on the same hand (Loomis et al. 1991). The authors suggested, that “the effective tactual field of view for this task is approximately equal to one finger pad”. Better results were found when stimuli consisting of matrices of vibrotactile point stimuli were presented to two fingers on different hands than when the two fingers were on the same hand. Dividing the stimulation onto two fingers on the same hand gave poorer performance than stimulation to one finger. The differences were attributed to attention mechanisms (Craig 1985). Also, another study (Ballesteros et al. 1998) found an advantage for two index fingers scanning symmetrical 2D figures in parallel comparison with one-finger scanning. In an investigation of curvature, an advantage for multi-finger grip compared with one-finger tracing was found (Davidson 1972). In spite of the advantage demonstrated, for some cases of two-finger use, contour following as an exploratory procedure for perception of shape is often performed with only one finger (Lederman and Klatzky 1987). It has even been found that the use of one finger is spontaneously used for exploration of raised line drawings (Symmons and Richardson 2000).

In an experiment on identification of European countries by reading embossed contour maps the aim was to investigate if performance can be increased by the use of two fingers (thumb and index finger) instead of one finger. In the two-finger situation the reader explored opposite sides of the country map. The result was that there was no significant difference between one- and two-finger exploration (Jansson and Monaci 2003). In an experiment with different two-finger combinations (index finger–thumb, two index fingers, index–middle finger) no significant differences were found even if there was a tendency to the condition thumb and index finger to be more efficient (Jansson and Monaci 2004).

In sum, the evidence for 2D patterns is mixed. Sometimes it was found that using more than one finger was advantageous; in other studies no difference was found between the use of one finger and more fingers. It should be noted, however, that the tasks reported about here were 2D patterns and thus not among the most natural kinds of objects.

Number of fingers used for identification of 3D objects

In contrast, experiments on more genuinely natural tasks, such as identification of 3D objects, with different number of fingers gave unambiguous results. Studies have been made concerning the identification of both real objects and virtual forms. Decreasing the number of fingers exploring real objects from five to one impaired performance in identifying objects (Klatzky et al. 1993). Another study got related results with two fingers and one finger in a sorting task (O’Modhrain 1999). An experiment with several numbers of fingers found highly significant differences in proportions of errors between conditions, where one finger and two or more fingers, respectively, were involved, but no significant differences between conditions with two to ten fingers (Jansson and Monaci 2004). Also exploration times were significantly different to a high degree between the one-finger condition on one side and the two-finger and more-fingers conditions on the other side. According to this study, it is important to have at least two fingers in use.

Experiments with multi-finger haptic displays demonstrate the same results. In a study with up to three such contact areas, it was found that no improvement of identifications of shape was obtained when the number was increased from one to three (Frisoli et al. 2005). Many other issues concerning multi-contact points in interaction with real and virtual objects were discussed in a recent book (Barbagli et al. 2005).

Effects of decreasing spatially distributed cutaneous information within a contact area

In the studies just described (except the last ones) the contact areas provided spatially distributed cutaneous information, as the area in contact with the object was not artificially constrained and the skin was compliable. In a few experiments on the effects of the information obtained in such situations significant differences in performance were found in several tasks between two conditions of cutaneous information: (1) information spatially distributed over the skin surface as in nature and (2) information artificially constrained by a sheath making it the same over the whole skin surface involved, similar to the conditions in nearly all haptic displays. The performance in conditions without spatial distribution of information was inferior to conditions with such information. Spatial acuity, pressure sensitivity, edge orientation detection, and detection of a rigid mass in a tissue were found to be impaired when spatial distribution of information was lacking (Lederman and Klatzky 1999).

A cutaneous area without any constraints already under static conditions provides rich spatially distributed information, including microstructure properties such as the successive elevation of edges and contours, and still more spatio-temporal information during the exploration. Under dynamic conditions also, texture gradients useful for judging 3D properties of 2D tactile pictures can be perceived haptically (Holmes et al. 1998).

Problem

The results referred to above, demonstrate that both number of contact areas and increased cutaneous information at each area may be important for the identification of objects. The constraints of information concerning these factors in haptic displays are probable candidates for the explanation of the much poorer performance of object identification with these displays than in the real world. Haptic displays today have only one contact area or a few such areas, and the information at each of them is typically the same over the whole contact area, thus not at all as rich as the natural information. This suggests two ways of improving the efficiency of haptic displays: (1) increasing the number of contact areas and (2) providing increased cutaneous information at each contact area.Footnote 1

As discussed above, each of these two options has been shown before to be important. The aim of the present investigation was to make a comparison of them and investigate their relative importance for identification of objects. The comparison is made by “simulating” potential technical developments in experiments with real objects, where the information is constrained in ways similar to those in present-day’s haptic displays.

Methods

Identification task

The participants’ task was similar to the task given in (Klatzky et al. 1993; Lederman and Klatzky 1999). In each of the experimental conditions the participants should identify 101 common well-known objects. In a pilot experiment with five participants it was checked that it was possible to identify these objects without vision under optimal haptic conditions, i.e., free exploration with two hands. One of the objects in the pilot experiment that was found to be difficult to identify was replaced by another. The objects that passed this test are given in Table 1.

The collection of objects had many different forms and sizes. There were objects that were small in all three dimensions, such as a eraser (6×2×1 cm), objects, for example knitting-needles, that were relatively large in one dimension (32 cm) but small in the other two dimensions, objects that are relatively large in two dimensions (an ash tray with a diameter of 22 cm) but small in the third dimension. All of them had one dimension that was less than 5 cm (the maximum opening of the clip). A majority were solid objects, a minority compliant ones.

As objects cannot be handled satisfactorily in all conditions, especially not with only one finger, they were placed in a clip (see Fig. 1). This arrangement meant that weight could not be a basis for the judgments, nor any other information from handling the objects. Before the experimental session the participants were allowed to see and feel the clip. No advance information about the objects was presented. For the experiment the participants were blindfolded and provided with headphones producing white noise, in order to make the information purely haptic. Before any objects were presented, the participants were allowed to feel the clip again. Each of the 101 objects was presented once one by one in random orders different for each participant. The experimenter tapped the participant’s hand to indicate when exploration should start. If there was no reply within 1 min, the participant was required to guess. Pauses between the object explorations were allowed if the participants’ wanted. The total time for the experiment was about 2 h.

Experimental conditions

Four numbers of contact areas and three amounts of information were used, thus in total 12 conditions.

Number of contact areas

The following numbers of contact areas were used (all on the same, preferred, hand): one finger (index finger), two fingers (thumb and index finger), three fingers (thumb, index, and long finger), and all five fingers. The choice of these finger combinations means that in all conditions except the one-finger condition an opposing thumb was available. The fingers not to be used were taped to the palm.

Information at contact areas

The following conditions were used:

  1. 1.

    Bare finger(s), a natural condition, providing spatially distributed cutaneous information within the contact area,

  2. 2.

    Fingers equipped with a molded sheath similar to the one in (Lederman and Klatzky 1999), kept in place by a rubber glove (see Fig. 2), which provided the same information to the whole contact areaFootnote 2

  3. 3.

    Fingers equipped with a rubber glove only (a control condition to see the effect of the rubber glove available in condition 2 but not in condition 1).

Procedure

The participants’ were randomly assigned to one of the 12 experimental groups, 10 to each group. They were blindfolded and equipped with headphones delivering white noise sufficient to prevent any sounds to be heard. The objects were presented in random orders, different for each participant.

The participants were first instructed about what contact areas to be used. Especially, it was emphasized in the sheaths conditions that no area outside the sheaths should be used. In the bare fingers and fingers with gloves condition the area to be used was not equally strictly defined, but it was tried to restrict the areas used, by instruction and supervision, to about the same size as those used in the fingers with sheaths condition. All the sessions were videotaped, and the participants’ conformation to the rules could be checked also afterwards. Otherwise, there was no specific instruction about exploratory procedure to use. The experimenter tapped the participant’s hand indicating that the exploration should start and the maximum time allowed for each object was 1 min. The task was to name the object as soon as possible. If no response was given within the time allowed, the participant was asked to guess. For each object explored the participant’s verbal answer was written down, and the exploration time from start or exploration until naming of the object was measured with a stopwatch.

Participants

The 120 participants (41 males and 79 females) were university students who served either as a course requirement or for payment. Their mean age was 25 years (SD=5 years), closely the same in all the groups.

Results

The verbal responses were judged to be correct or wrong by the experimenter. In some, very few cases, where it was doubtful how the answer should be judged, the two authors made a common judgment. Percent errors were calculated for each participant, as well as the means of the exploration times for all the 101 objects. The means of these individual values for each experimental group are shown in Fig. 3.

An ANOVA for Percent errors showed highly significant effects for both independent variables, for number of fingers F(3, 108)=11.20, p<0.001, and for Information at contact areas F(2, 108)=310.69, p<0.001. In fact, the p values were much below 0.001. There was no significant interaction, F(6, 108)=0.910, p=0.49. In the bare fingers condition the Tukey HSD (Honestly significant difference) test identified significant differences between one finger and all the other conditions, two fingers and three fingers (p<0.05) and five fingers (p<0.01), in the fingers with gloves condition between one finger and three fingers (p<0.05), but no significant differences in the fingers with sheaths condition.

An ANOVA for exploration times gave similar results: for number of fingers F (3, 108)=21.37, p<0.001 for Information at contact areas F(2, 108)=6787.89, p<0.001. Again the p values were much below 0.001. There was a moderately significant interaction effect: F(6, 108)=2.62, p<0.05. According to Tukey HSD test there were significant differences in the bare fingers condition between one finger and both two and five fingers (p<0.01), for the fingers with gloves condition between one-finger and all the other-finger conditions (p<0.001), but no significant differences for the fingers with sheaths condition.

Discussion

Main results

The most important result was the enormous effect of constraining the information at the contact areas. When the conditions were constrained in a way similar to those in the haptic displays the performance deteriorated considerably, concerning both percent errors and exploration times. The lack of this information when using haptic displays is probably the main reason for the only limited success for these devices in many contexts.

Further, it is important to observe that adding more contact areas with constrained information had no significant effect on either dependent variable. This result suggests that not much, if any, improvement of haptic displays for identification of objects can be expected with adding more contact areas with the point-type contact. This result is in agreement with the suggestion made in (Lederman and Klatzky 1999) that the results in experiments with single-finger exploration can be generalized to multi-finger conditions. Confer also the result of the experiment mentioned above on shape perception with a haptic display arrangement with up to three contact areas (Frisoli et al. 2005).

In order to provide information at the contact areas corresponding to the capacity of the fingertip skin, much technological development is needed. An effort to provide such information was the high-density tactile array developed at John Hopkins University (20×20 probes 0.5 mm apart) (Pawluk et al. 1998). Such a complicated display with its large technical superstructure would not be suitable for addition to a haptic display, but some device with at least similar capacity would be wanted. A technically simpler solution was developed at Harvard University (6×6 probes 2 mm apart) (Wagner et al. 2004). Other efforts were described in (Jungmann and Schlaak 2002), and building of new tactile devices in the form of matrices of pins to add to haptic displays is going on within the EU project ENACTIVE Network of Excellence (IST-2002-002114).

It should be noted that there are also reports about software options improving the perception of object properties via a haptic display (cf. Minsky 1995; Robles-De-La-Torre and Hayward 2001). Another study demonstrated that curvature could be perceived from a deformation trajectory on the skin provided by a relatively simple device, especially for active multi-point contacts (Dostmohamed and Hayward 2005).

Future evaluations will show how successful all these options are. Ideally, they would allow miniature spatio-temporal information to be presented in a useful way, improving the possibilities to identify virtual objects.

Some other comments

The objects could not be manipulated in any of the conditions, as the objects were clipped, an arrangement that was necessary in order to keep the same arrangements for all conditions, as there is no reasonable way to handle objects with one finger. This had probably a negative effect on performance, one of the missed properties being that of weight. However, this arrangement can be expected to have the same effect on all the conditions, and it is not critical for the conclusions of the present relative results. Anyhow, the performance in general is probably below what should be obtained in completely unconstrained conditions. The pilot experiment with free exploration, before the choice of objects suggests that there would have been no or very few errors in a control group given unconstrained arrangements.

The majority of the real objects were rigid. As virtual objects are usually not completely rigid with today’s technology, the results are especially applicable when the virtual objects are rigid. However, the relative performance between the experimental conditions is probably not effected by this fact, as the objects were the same in all of them.

There were some properties that were different between the conditions. The bare fingers condition had availability to thermal information, which the fingers with gloves condition hardly had, and the fingers with sheaths certainly had not. Further, the contact area used was not equally strictly controlled, and it may have been somewhat larger in the bare fingers and fingers with gloves condition. However, the potential effects of these properties can hardly be a main reason for the enormous difference in performance in these conditions compared with that of the fingers with sheaths condition.

The fingers with gloves condition was introduced to check the effect of the contact between object and observer being via a rubber glove. It had some effect, but the performance was not too different from that in the bare fingers condition. The great impairment of performance in the Fingers with sheaths condition can thus not depend to any large extent on the existence of the glove in this case, even if the gloves meant some loss of cutaneous information.

Conclusion

The experimental situations with constrained haptic information in this investigation can be seen as “simulations” of haptic displays of multi-finger displays with different amounts of information at the contact areas. The results suggest that the most important way to improve the usability of haptic displays, at least for identification of objects, is not to increase the number of contact areas without spatially distributed information. A much larger improvement can be expected if spatially distributed information is made available within each contact area. If that is made, an improvement of performance can be expected also with an increased number of contact areas. Increasing only the number of contact areas will not give the same result.

Notes

  1. 1.

    The choice of these two options for improvement of haptic displays does not exclude, of course, that there may be other options as well.

  2. 2.

    All participants were seen before the experiment proper for molding the sheath(s) to suit the shape of their finger(s) participating in the experiment and/or to check if any of those made for earlier participants fitted sufficiently well. Forty-five different sheaths of the 110 needed were used. The sheaths were produced in the following way. A cast of the pad of the distal phalanx of the finger in question was created by placing it in a form with alginate. Two casts of this cast were molded in paraffin. The size of one of them was increased by dipping it in melted paraffin (as when candles are made) in order to make it correspond to the size of the finger plus the sheath. A cast of the larger paraffin cast was made in plaster. In the larger plaster cast polyester plastic was poured and three sheets of 168 g glass-fiber were placed there together with the smaller paraffin cast. After being solidified the sheath was trimmed to form a smooth outer surface. The sheath was kept in place by a thin (1 mm) rubber glove in a size suitable for each participant.
